GT_Sentence: shaw, the chairman of the board, provided the only comment: “i would like to say this has been a long, difficult case, and i want to thank all the parties, and especially thank our staff for the diligence, hard work, and all the parties for just the professionalism and decorum shown on this case.”

GT_Sentence: the decision disappointed the landowners, who were not allowed to speak at the meeting but issued a statement vowing to continue fighting to keep their land by appealing in court.

blaine smith, a black man who is one of the heirs of 600 acres that came into their family in the 1920s, said in a statement: “we’re determined to keep fighting against this attempt to take our ancestral land from us.”

GT_Sentence: the construction would also have an impact on other black residents in the community, who believe it would affect their quality of life.

but, some legal experts and landowners told capital b that black communities aren’t experiencing “just” and “fair” processes and say there needs to be more accountability to stop government abuse of eminent domain.

“as black people, ownership of land and property is more valuable than a dollar amount because it allows a certain type of economic freedom that we are often deprived of,” attorney sharika robinson told capital b last year. “i don’t know what is ‘just’ about replacing that economic liberty with a dollar amount that will not increase in value.”
LLM_Sentence: as black people, ownership of land and property is more valuable than a dollar amount because it allows a certain type of economic freedom that we are often deprived of.

GT_Sentence: “georgia law does not permit a private company to take land through eminent domain unless the land will be put to a public use,” said bill maurer, senior attorney for institute for justice who represents the landowners. “building a rail spur that will only be used by a few private companies, and not the public at large, is not a public use. we look forward to making it clear to the court that the [public service commission] made an error in considering sandersville’s land grab as a public use.”
LLM_Sentence: building a rail spur that will only be used by a few private companies, and not the public at large, is not a public use. we look forward to making it clear to the court that the [public service commission] made an error in considering sandersvilles land grab as a public use.
Title_GT: senior attorney for institute for justice
Title_LLM: senior attorney for institute for justice
Justification_GT: the property owners are represented by the nonprofit institute for justice, a public interest law firm.
Title_and_Justification_GT: senior attorney for institute for justice the property owners are represented by the nonprofit institute for justice, a public interest law firm.

GT_Sentence: benjamin tarbutton iii, the owner of sandersville railroad, has contended this development is expected to create 20 temporary construction jobs, a dozen permanent jobs with an average salary and benefits package of $90,000, and generate over $1.5 million annually for hancock county.

GT_Sentence: other residents told capital b they feared potential damage to their homes from the train.

there are also environmental concerns, said jamie rush, senior staff attorney with the southern poverty law center’s economic justice project who represents the no railroad in our community coalition, a coalition of residents who aren’t losing their property to the railroad but will be affected by the train.
Title_GT: senior staff attorney, southern poverty law center’s economic justice project
Justification_GT: who represents the no railroad in our community coalition
Title_and_Justification_GT: senior staff attorney, southern poverty law center’s economic justice project who represents the no railroad in our community coalition

GT_Sentence: “the reality is if you’ve ever lived near a train, or you’ve ever ridden on a train or been near a train, it’s not the same as trucks driving by,” rush said last year. “even if the train is not going through your property, the fact that a train is near your property — all of the noise pollution, the vibrations of a train … all of that affects your property value, your peace of mind and your home.”
Title_GT: senior staff attorney, southern poverty law center’s economic justice project
Justification_GT: who represents the no railroad in our community coalition

GT_Sentence: in april, capital b reported that thomas k. bond, a hearing officer with the georgia public service commission, approved sandersville’s request to move forward with condemning properties to construct their railroad spur.

“the proposed condemnation … serves a legitimate public purpose and is necessary for the proper accommodation of the business,” bond wrote. “the petition of sandersville railroad, as amended, is granted.”
